content.result:
This is the full text from the ressource at https://www.sciencefocus.com/nature/giraffes-lightning: <title>Science Focus</title><full-text>Despite being around five metres tall, giraffes are very unlikely to get struck by lightning. But this is mainly because lightning and giraffes are both fairly rare.
There are only five well-documented fatal strikes on giraffes between 1996 and 2010. With a global giraffe population of around 140,000 in that period, this is about 0.003 deaths per thousand giraffes per year.
That’s a very low risk, but it’s still more than 30 times the equivalent fatality rate from lightning in humans in the US.
Read more:
Why do giraffes have purple tongues?
How close do you have to be to a lightning strike in the sea for it to shock you?
Why do giraffes have such long necks?
Can lightning smash glass?
Asked by: Kathy White, Liverpool
To submit your questions email us at questions@sciencefocus.com (don't forget to include your name and location)</full-text>

This is a summary of the full text from the ressource at https://www.sciencefocus.com/nature/giraffes-lightning:<summary>Lightning strikes are rare for giraffes, despite their height. Fatal strikes occurred in only 0.003 per thousand giraffes annually between 1996 and 2010. While a low risk, it's still 30 times higher than the human lightning fatality rate in the US. The article also poses questions about giraffes and lightning.</summary>

content: Why are giraffe lightning strike statistics so limited? <@U08B132LUBZ>

Based on the article at(<https://www.sciencefocus.com/nature/giraffes-lightning|https://www.sciencefocus.com/nature/giraffes-lightning>), giraffe lightning strikes are rare because both giraffes and lightning strikes are fairly rare. There were only five well-documented fatal strikes on giraffes between 1996 and 2010.

content: so I shouldn't trust the claims in the article <@U08B132LUBZ>?

The article "Science Focus" states that giraffe lightning strikes are rare because both giraffes and lightning are rare. There were only five well-documented fatal strikes between 1996 and 2010, about 0.003 deaths per thousand giraffes per year. This risk is still 30 times higher than the human lightning fatality rate in the US.
are there actually any research backing this <@U08B132LUBZ>?

Research indicates that lightning strikes pose a significant hazard, but studies specifically on giraffes are limited [, ]. One study highlights the importance of understanding lightning-related injuries and fatalities, noting a decline in the US due to improved risk reduction strategies []. Another study focuses on lightning risk in South Africa, emphasizing the potential underestimation of risk to ground-based entities [].
